page.title: 06WILDLIFE IN TERLING
page.content: Terling is surrounded by farmland with a good selection of trees, but Dutch Elm Disease has destroyed most of the elms. The area abounds with wildlife including hares, rabbits, pheasants, partridges, moorhens and numerous smaller birds and animals. There is an occasional siting of woodpeckers, tree creepers, heron and a good number of finches. Deer are very rare here now, but one was seen in 1984. Foxes, jays, magpies, and crows are rarely seen since they are kept to a minimum by the gamekeepers who rear pheasants all round here.There are not so many frogs now.The River Ter contains among others trout, eels, stickleback and minnows. Also water voles can often be seen.Terling Village and the surrounding area is fortunate in still retaining it's many small woods and hedges virtually unchanged.
